headline: 'Jumbo' CDs Stay Flat
summary: The average yield on six-month "jumbo" CDs remained unchanged at 0.17% from the week earlier.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: World-Wide
summary: What's News World-Wide April 23, 2013.

headline: Rate Rise Could Hit 'Target' Funds
summary: Millions of workers saving for retirement risk losing part of their nest eggs if interest rates jump. The cause for concern: target-date mutual funds.

headline: Authorities Investigating Smoking Plane
summary: Singapore Airlines and authorities in Thailand are investigating smoke warnings that activated cargo-hold extinguishers on a flight from Singapore to Dhaka, Bangladesh.

summary: Federal regulators are expected to warn banks against making short-term loans that have been criticized for resembling payday loans and trapping consumers into taking out debt that they can't repay.

headline: From Locally Sourced to French Flavored

summary: Police who raided a Monmouth County man's home in 2007 were justified in using a "flash-bang" device as a diversion before entering, New Jersey's Supreme Court ruled Tuesday.

headline: The BlackBerry of BlackBerry Users' Dreams
summary: New Q10 has a smart keyboard, fast browser and impressive camera features that may keep fans loyal, says Katherine Boehret.

headline: Politicians Plead Not Guilty
summary: New York state Sen. Malcolm Smith and New York City Councilman Dan Halloran were among six politicians who pleaded not guilty Tuesday in an alleged corruption scheme to sell a seat on the New York City mayoral ballot.

headline: Why Annie's Charges More for Mac & Cheese

headline: City Puts Bronx Future on Ice
summary: Bronx's Kingsbridge Armory will be converted into one of the world's largest indoor ice-sports facilities, city officials said Tuesday, marking a culmination of decades of efforts to redevelop the long-vacant structure in the city's poorest borough.

headline: ING Korea Unit Draws Five Possible Bidders
summary: Five potential bidders are conducting preliminary due diligence as they consider an offer for ING Groep's Korean life-insurance operations.

headline: For Once, Knicks Catch a Break

summary: There's a lot of talk about Barbra Streisand these days. As if there isn't always a lot of talk about Barbra Streisand? Right?

summary: After a slow start, New York comes out on fire in 2nd half to go up 2-0 in first round of playoffs.

headline: Israel's Top Cop Offers U.S. Terrorism Advice

headline: U.S., South Korea Reach Nuclear Deal

summary: "The great thing about Reese is she's a character actress stuck in a movie star's body," said Jeff Nichols at a screening of his new movie, "Mud," on Sunday.

headline: What Would Angela Say?
summary: Angela Merkel is widely expected to win a third term as German chancellor in September. Tap through the dates below to read some of her opinions on key events in the euro-zone crisis.

headline: A Spring Fete at the Met

headline: Japan's Croesus Retail Trust Prices IPO
summary: Croesus Retail Trust has priced its IPO at 75 U.S. cents per unit, setting up a flotation worth about $300 million that could be Singapore's second-biggest IPO this year.

summary: A baby is born in China's quake zone, voters queue up in Bhutan, vendors make way for a train in Thailand, and more.

headline: In Japan, Television Viewing Doesn't Have to Take a Back Seat
summary: When selling car navigation systems, Japanese retailer Autobacs touts a special add-on: kits that convert the mapping gadgets into televisions, so drivers can watch their favorite shows.

headline: School's Reserve Fund Draws Ire
summary: Irate Wisconsin legislative leaders are threatening to withhold funds from the University of Wisconsin and force a tuition freeze after discovering the school has quietly amassed a $650 million reserve fund.

headline: Toward Eternity
summary: Horton Foote's "The Trip to Bountiful" is one of this country's greatest plays, saying at least as much about our national character as "The Glass Menagerie" or "Our Town."

headline: The Smorgasbord That Thinks It's a Weight-Loss Plan
summary: Heeding popular nutritional advice, some health-conscious consumers have traded in the traditional breakfast, lunch and dinner for a daylong stream of mini meals.

summary: U.S. regulators approved lithium-ion batteries for Boeing Co.'s 787 jets based primarily on tests and analyses performed by the company and its partners, rather than independent government technical efforts.

summary: In the race for mayor, there's a clear and substantial wealth divide between candidates with private-sector income and those who earn their living working for the government.

summary: New York Yankee first baseman Mark Teixeira's rehab from a wrist injury is going a little more slowly than he'd hoped.

summary: The trial of a former dictator accused of genocide has divided the country and pitted judge against judge, becoming the biggest test yet of Guatemala's fragile justice system.

summary: The eyes of the marathon industry are fixed on New York, since its five-borough race features larger numbers of runners and spectators than any other in America.

If it works out at Thursday's NFL draft as well as it did then, even the biggest fans of Darrelle Revis will have little reason to complain.

headline: Remember: It's Only April

summary: It turns out this was not a model of post-9/11 antiterror coordination.

summary: The 4% FAA spending cut that somehow delays 40% of flights.

summary: The much-maligned name of college football's postseason will change after this season, when the sport adds a playoff.

headline: GMO Food Technology Doesn't Help the Poor Very Much
summary: Robert Paarlberg's "The World Needs Genetically Modified Foods" (op-ed, April 15) gets it exactly backward. The technology does not help the hungry—the majority of whom are farmers in the developing world. Why not? Because GMOs leave cash-poor farmers dependent on buying seeds, fertilizer and chemicals all while providing uneven results.

headline: Maurizio Pollini: Not as Others See Him
summary: The Italian pianist offers a rare interview and his own view of his artistry.

headline: China Woes Hit Yum's Earnings
summary: Yum Brands reported a 26% drop in first-quarter earnings as the fast-food chain's business in China was hurt by health concerns about its chicken supplies.

headline: Investors Cheer Caesars Spinoff Plan

headline: Penney Taps AlixPartners

summary: Customers of Charles Schwab Corp. were unable to place trades using the discount brokerage's website or log on to their accounts through mobile devices late Tuesday.

headline: Syria Used Chemical Arms, Israel Says

headline: Hedge-Fund Manager Ends Talk of French Posting
summary: Hedge-fund manager Marc Lasry told investors he will remain at his Avenue Capital firm, quashing speculation that he would be appointed as the next ambassador to France.

headline: China's Shaken Trust
summary: An earthquake shows the decline in confidence in the Communist Party.

summary: The European Commission will review IntercontinentalExchange's bid to buy NYSE Euronext, enabling the exchange operators to avoid a potentially longer examination by national antitrust regulators.

headline: Crude Oil Ends Flat
summary: Oil futures ended nearly flat as traders shrugged off weak global manufacturing data and a fake tweet that rattled investors and focused on an upswing in the stock market.

summary: Early gains in U.S. Treasurys fueled by discouraging economic data were erased by the end of Tuesday's session as investors shifted into riskier assets.

summary: Investor demand is high for Nike's new $1 billion corporate-bond offering, its first sale since 2003.

summary: Commodities retreated Tuesday after weaker manufacturing activity in China and the U.S., the world's two largest consumers of raw materials, fanned worries about demand.

headline: Guilty Plea Expected in Fake-Drugs Case

headline: Brazil Real Ends Slightly Weaker
summary: Brazil's real weakened slightly against the dollar after the release of disappointing Chinese data.

headline: Photos of the Day: April 23
summary: In today's pictures, a farmer finds World War I munitions in France, poisoned oak trees are cut down at Auburn University, France legalizes same-sex marriage, and more.

headline: Whirlwind Gayle Makes History
summary: Heard on the Pitch: West Indies batsmen hits fastest century; Wimbledon increases tennis prize money

headline: Dortmund Dismayed by Götze's Transfer
summary: Supporters in shock as German rival Bayern Munich poaches star midfielder.

summary: Researchers are set to begin a clinical trial of a blood test that may distinguish between children with autism and those with other developmental issues.

summary: Arch Coal lost a round in its battle to build a mountaintop mine in West Virginia as a federal appeals court sided on a key point with regulators who want to stop the project.

summary: Democrats will have to defend an open Senate seat in a red state.

summary: Non-recess recess appointments? Who cares?

headline: What the Falk?
summary: The United Nations indulges anti-Semitism. Ho-hum.

summary: Germany's Bundesliga isn't tops in the "fancy" department but might be the most competitive among Europe's top leagues.

summary: A federal judge ordered the FDA to move forward with enacting an overhaul of U.S. food-safety regulations that were signed into law two years ago.

summary: Bank of France Governor Christian Noyer said France needs to step up the pace of structural changes, including more loosening of its rigid labor market.

headline: BlackBerry's Keyboard Is Back—Will It Sell?
